conclusion: Analyze the thermodynamic process for an ideal gas going from state A to state B to state C, and calculate the total heat transferred.
The process follows path A → B → C as shown in the p-V diagram.
The temperature at state A is 27°C = 300 K (converting to Kelvin).
The axes are pressure (p) in 10⁵ Pa and volume (V) in 10⁻³ m³.
State A: p = 1 × 10⁵ Pa, V = 6 × 10⁻³ m³.
State B: p = 2 × 10⁵ Pa, V = 6 × 10⁻³ m³.
State C: p = 3 × 10⁵ Pa, V = 2 × 10⁻³ m³.
Process A → B is a constant volume (isochoric/isometric) process.
Process B → C is a diagonal line, which is neither constant pressure nor constant volume.
For process A → B, work done W₁ = 0 (since dV = 0).
For process B → C, work done W₂ = -1000 J using the area under the curve.
For state A, n·R = 2 J/K using pV = nRT.
For state B, T_B = 600 K using pV = nRT.
For state C, T_C = 300 K using pV = nRT.
For process A → B, ΔU₁ = 1500 J using ΔU = (5/2)nR(T_B - T_A).
For process B → C, ΔU₂ = -1500 J using ΔU = (5/2)nR(T_C - T_B).
For process A → B, Q₁ = 1500 J using Q = ΔU + W.
For process B → C, Q₂ = -500 J using Q = ΔU + W.
The total heat transferred Q_total = 1000 J.
The total heat transferred by the gas during the complete cycle from A to B to C is 1000 J (or 1.0 kJ).
